IA
Indiana Art Activist

Activism Timeline

A chronological journey through art and activism in Indiana.

1883
Women's Suffrage, Education
Indianapolis

Founding the Art Association of Indianapolis

May Wright Sewall

While not a visual artwork, her 'work' was the creation of the institutions themselves. She leveraged her influence to create spaces where women could organize, learn, and engage with the arts, laying the cultural foundation of Indianapolis.

Read full profile →
1933
Labor Rights
Bloomington (IU Auditorium)

A Social History of Indiana

Thomas Hart Benton

A sprawling mural cycle that places the laborer and the common person at the center of Indiana's history. It explicitly links the state's progress to the physical toil of its workers and acknowledges the political struggles of the working class.

Read full profile →
1940
Labor Rights
Fowler (U.S. Post Office)

Rest during Prairie Plowing

Nat Werner

A relief sculpture that humanizes the agricultural laborer, depicting a moment of rest. It acknowledges the exhaustion and humanity of the worker behind the agricultural production.

Read full profile →
1941
Labor Rights
Pendleton (U.S. Post Office)

Loggers

William F. Kaeser

A mural depicting the logging industry, emphasizing the collective effort and physical strength required by the workers, serving as a permanent tribute to the region's working-class roots.

Read full profile →
1942
Labor Rights
Bedford (U.S. Post Office)

Limestone Quarry Workers

John Fabion

A relief sculpture capturing the dangerous and physically demanding work of quarrying limestone. It honors the dignity of the industrial worker during an era when labor rights were a central national conversation.

Read full profile →
1965
Civil Rights
Various Collections

The Confederacy: Mississippi

Robert Indiana (Robert Clark)

Part of his 'Confederacy' series, this work is a blunt critique of Southern racism during the Civil Rights era. It features a map of Mississippi and references the 1964 murders of civil rights workers, condemning the state's violent resistance to justice.

Read full profile →
1967 / 1976
Women's Suffrage
Various Collections

The Mother of Us All (Posters/Designs)

Robert Indiana (Suffrage Work)

Indiana created the set design and costumes for the Virgil Thomson/Gertrude Stein opera 'The Mother of Us All', which chronicles the life of Susan B. Anthony. His pop-art aesthetic brought a modern, graphic energy to the story of the suffrage movement.

Read full profile →
1990s–2000s
Social Justice, Holocaust Memory
IU Bloomington

Written in Memory (Series)

Jeffrey A. Wolin

This series documents the stories of Holocaust survivors. By combining portraits with the survivors' own written memories, Wolin ensures these personal histories are preserved and witnesses to the atrocities of the past are honored.

Read full profile →
2007-2011
Racial Justice, Historical Reconciliation
Indianapolis (Not Installed)

E Pluribus Unum

Fred Wilson

This controversial project proposed remixing the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument by isolating the sole African American figure (a formerly enslaved man) and elevating him on a new pedestal holding a flag of the African diaspora. The project was cancelled due to public controversy.

Read full profile →
2008
Political Change
Various Collections (Global)

HOPE

Robert Indiana (Robert Clark)

Created for Barack Obama's 2008 presidential campaign, the 'HOPE' sculpture utilizes Indiana's signature stacked typography. Proceeds from the print sales were donated to the campaign, marking a direct intersection of Pop Art and political activism.

Read full profile →
2015
Racial Justice
IU Eskenazi Museum of Art (Bloomington)

Poplar Trees

Samuel Levi Jones

A diptych made from the skins of deconstructed books. The title references the song 'Strange Fruit' and the history of lynching (poplar trees), using the medium itself to critique how history and law have been used to oppress rather than protect.

Read full profile →
2020
Civil Rights, Police Brutality
Indianapolis (Archived by IndyPL)

We the People

Gary Gee

Part of the 'Murals for Racial Justice', this panel depicts a diverse group of protesters demanding justice. The work contrasts the constitutional ideal of 'We the People' with the reality of police brutality and systemic inequality faced by marginalized communities.

Read full profile →
2020
Racial Justice, Police Brutality
Indianapolis (Archived by IndyPL)

Blkkk Lives Don't Matter

Mechi Shakur (Demetrius Green)

A powerful, eight-panel work created on boarded-up windows during the 2020 protests. The provocative title and imagery serve as a direct confrontation of the violence against Black bodies, challenging the viewer to acknowledge the disparity in how lives are valued.

Read full profile →
2020
Social Justice (General)
Indianapolis

American Duality

Israel Solomon

This piece explores the split experience of American life, highlighting the stark differences in safety, policing, and opportunity faced by Black Americans versus their white counterparts.

Read full profile →
2020
Racial Justice, Placemaking
Fort Wayne (McMillen Park)

McMillen Park Basketball Court Murals

Andre Portee (AbsorbALL)

A massive, vibrant mural painted directly onto the basketball courts of McMillen Park. The project revitalized a gray, neglected space into a colorful destination, celebrating Black culture and providing a beautiful, dignified space for youth recreation.

Read full profile →
2020
Women's Suffrage, Racial Justice
Indianapolis (Indiana Statehouse)

Together

Kassie Woodworth

Commissioned for the 19th Amendment Centennial, this quilt commemorates the suffrage movement while explicitly acknowledging the racial divide within it. It honors the women of color whose fight for voting rights continued long after 1920.

Read full profile →
2020
Women's Suffrage
Decatur / Indiana Statehouse

nINeteenth

Shelby Nower

A celebratory painting depicting women triumphantly casting their first votes. Nower integrated the names of prominent Indiana suffragists into the clothing of the figures, turning the painting into a historical document of the movement's leaders.

Read full profile →
2020
Women's Suffrage
Indianapolis (Work travels nationally)

Her Flag (Indiana Stripe)

Bonnie Fillenwarth

Created as Indiana's contribution to the national 'Her Flag' collaborative project. The stripe illustrates key Hoosier suffragists, visually weaving Indiana's specific history into the larger national tapestry of the 19th Amendment ratification.

Read full profile →
2025
Social Connection, Placemaking
Bloomington (Allen & Fairview Streets)

McDoel Blooms

Rachel Kavathe

A street mural project designed to calm traffic and beautify the McDoel Gardens neighborhood. The design features native flora and garden imagery, reflecting the neighborhood's history and the shared values of its residents.

Read full profile →
August 2020
Racial Justice
Indianapolis (Indiana Avenue)

Black Lives Matter Street Mural

The Eighteen Art Collective

A massive street mural where each of the 18 artists was assigned one letter of the phrase 'Black Lives Matter.' The mural is a vibrant affirmation of Black life and culture, located on a street with deep historical significance to Indianapolis's Black community.

Read full profile →
Early 1900s
Women's Suffrage
Evansville, Indiana

Suffrage Movement Involvement & Guild Founding

Florita Eichel

Eichel used her position to bridge political activism and the arts in Southern Indiana. Her legacy is the professionalization of the arts in Evansville and her early grassroots work securing the vote for women in the state.

Read full profile →
June 2021
Civil Rights, Immigration
Fort Wayne (4335 S Anthony Blvd)

Faces of the Fort: Southeast Mural

Kacy Jackson

This mural honors local figures Irene Paxia, who supports refugees, and William E. Warfield, a historic Black real estate investor. It celebrates the contributions of immigrants and Black leaders to the fabric of Fort Wayne.

Read full profile →
June 2021
Racial Justice, Inclusive Community
Fort Wayne (1514 St. Joseph Blvd)

Faces of the Fort: Northeast Mural

Benjamin Duke

The mural depicts Glynn Hines, a long-time advocate for racial justice, and Genevieve Meyer, a crusader against child marriage in Indiana. It highlights the ongoing fight for legislative and social protection of vulnerable groups.

Read full profile →
June 2021
Social Justice (General)
Fort Wayne (1818 Bluffton Road)

Faces of the Fort: Southwest Mural

Mitchell Egly

A tribute to diverse local leaders who have shaped the community's history. The mural serves as a visual history lesson, ensuring that the contributions of civil rights leaders and community builders are not forgotten.

Read full profile →
Ongoing
Environmental Justice
Borden, Indiana

Natural Pigment Works

Karen Boone

Her abstract paintings are literal pieces of the Indiana landscape. By refusing commercial, toxic paints in favor of earth-based materials, her work advocates for a sustainable relationship with the land.

Read full profile →
Ongoing
Environmental Justice, Zero Waste
Southern Indiana

Walk the Willow Sculptures

Justin Roberts & Shannon Davis-Roberts

Whimsical, large-scale woven sculptures (often figures or structures) that demonstrate how public art can be created with a zero-waste footprint. Their work emphasizes the beauty of natural, renewable materials.

Read full profile →
Ongoing
Climate Change Awareness
Bloomington

Artists for Climate Awareness

Pat Rowbottom

While her personal work often celebrates nature, her primary 'activist' work is organizational—facilitating exhibits that force the community to confront climate change and conservation issues.

Read full profile →
Ongoing
Immigration Detention Abolition
South Bend

Portraits/Illustrations

Angelica Frausto (Nerdy Brown Kid)

Her illustrations are often used in campaigns for organizations like the Detention Watch Network. They focus on the humanity, dreams, and resilience of those impacted by the immigration system, countering dehumanizing political narratives.

Read full profile →
Ongoing
Immigration, Community Safety
Indianapolis

Immigrantes Bienvenidos (Immigrants Welcome)

Beatriz Vasquez

A public installation designed to signal safety and welcome to Latinx neighbors. It uses the imagery of the Monarch butterfly—a symbol of natural, borderless migration—to advocate for the free movement and dignity of people.

Read full profile →
Ongoing
Immigration, Gender & LGBTQ+ Rights
Indianapolis (Haughville)

Paintings & Mixed Media

Nasreen Khan

Her mixed media works often combine natural elements with personal narrative, grappling with the feeling of 'otherness' in the Midwest and challenging the viewer to see the beauty in the marginalized and the reclaimed.

Read full profile →
Ongoing (Since 2005)
Social Connection
Indianapolis (Garfield Park)

Social Alchemy

Shauta Marsh & Jim Walker

'Social Alchemy' is a multi-year project exploring the concepts of utopia and dystopia, drawing inspiration from New Harmony, Indiana. It uses art, radio, and design to facilitate social connection and reimagine how communities can live better together.

Read full profile →
Ongoing (Since 2023)
Labor Rights for Artists
Indianapolis

Salaried Artist Employment Program

Artists At Work (Indianapolis Cohort)

This is not a single artwork but a radical labor model. It validates art as 'work' deserving of a living wage and health insurance, directly combating the precarious financial reality that many artists face.

Read full profile →
Recent
Immigration, Empathy
Bloomington (IU Museum)

Whispers from the Divide

Jawshing Arthur Liou

A video installation filmed along the US-Mexico border. Rather than focusing on political rhetoric, the work captures the atmospheric and physical reality of the borderlands, fostering empathy and offering a meditative look at the barriers we erect.

Read full profile →

Built for the community. Documenting art and activism across Indiana.
